comment: If he were replaced by a robot, you wouldn't even know it.  Tests were 10 question, multiple choice scantron.  We covered 20 chapters in about 16 weeks.  Talking Quantum Mechanics, Relativistic Motion, and Blackbody radiation in 4 1 hr sessions.  Homework is webassign, very difficult.  No extra credit, attendance doesn't matter.  He will curve.

Professor Smith is a tough professor not because of his clarity. He is a very good teacher but his tests can be pretty difficult. Definitely requires studying and after having him for two semesters in a row I would still take him again. Typical Physics professor difficulty, but definitely came out knowing a lot.

6 tests, 10 problems for each, all multiple choice (no partial credit), no grading curve. Rapid-fire delivers dozens of scattered conceptual formulas in his unorganized lectures. Most test questions are absurdly in-depth and difficult to grasp b/c WebAssign "practice problems" differ from what's on exams. Impossible to finish tests in only 50 mins.

Eric Smith is the worst professor i have ever had.  His test are 10 question multiple choice that count for 60% of your grade.  This in itself is retarded for a calculus based physics course. No partial credit on any tests. Only 25% of his class attended lectures because he always messed up equations. Not helpful at all and never gives study guides

Professor Smith is very good at teaching physics and helping you understand the concepts. However, the tests do not reflect what we learn. Tests are 10 questions, multiple choice. No extra credit, so it is hard to pass the class.

Prof. Smith isn't good at teaching physics. The material is hard and Smith doesn't make it any easier. Goes over example problems in the book in class and gets lost all the time. Gives multiple choice test with no partial credit. The best way to learn the subject is to teach yourself. His lab is very easy though.

He was a tough teacher and would get lost sometimes in the problems he would work through. Easily flustered and sometimes scattered; although, he did cover the material well and did a good job of deriving the equations so it was possible to reason them out logically. I would take again, maybe not everyone would though.

Smith's lecture class is set up poorly. Tests are 85% of your grade and are 10 multiple choice questions each. As a result your grade may not reflect how much you know. The questions are tough and differ from those in homework and class. Our class avg for test 1 was 56. There are no curves. Expect to earn a letter grade below what you're used too.

Had him for Physics lab. He spends a good amount of time explaining the lab before you start but he lays everything out very clearly. He drops one lab grade and doesn't require you to show your work. Easy A for a lab

This professor is supremely unhelpful. It is like his object is not to teach, but to torture. I have spent more time on this class than my calculus class. If the questions were just hard, I would be fine with that. However, all of the coursework is at least unreasonable and at most absolutely sadistic.

he knows the material but is terrible at teaching it. the problems he works in class are the examples from the books. he goes through about a chapter a day so don't miss class. If you don't have any prior knowledge of physics, you will struggle in this class. the class average on our first test was a 56 and he wouldn't curve the grades.

He is a clear speaker, has great notes to learn from, and the book is quality. I studied very hard for a B. Incredible subject and tons of useless (some of it) info to remember.  For helpfulness his e-mails were very weak and sometimes incomplete so that I had to ask again in another way.
Tests are much different style than the homework. Is available for help during Office hours. Scan-tron tests make no room for error.

Professor gives scantron:multiple guess 10-15 question tests that count 85% of grade. No problem solving need be shown, it doesn't count towards anything. Obscure conceptual questions that are not in the book or covered in class make up 1/2 of tests. Closed book / closed notes. Prof is always away from office & gets testy when asked questions.

HE IS A GREAT TEACHER THOUGH NO MORE OPEN BOOK OR NOTES, THE WAY HE TEACHES MAKE U UNDERSTAND THE CONCEPT IN THE COURSE. TAKE SMITH 100% BECAUSE Whitenton IS THE WORST PROFESSOR EVER IN THE PHYSIC DEPARTMENT AND WHITENTON ALWAYS CONTROLS TO PATTERSON.

I took the online version of this class. Honestly it was really easy. The labs and discussion articles were the only things that I had to think critically about. Otherwise one could study minimally and use Google for questions and you should do fine. It is almost like he pulls from a pool of entry level questions that every school uses.

I had Professor Smith for the lab course. He explained everything on the lab, including all the calculations, and in general we were out within an hour. If you take notes, it would be rare when you would need to look at the lab manual for clarification.

Please be advised and look at his updated syllabus before taking the class. The class is almost impossible to get an A in, you'd be lucky to make a B. Furthermore, professor Smith will not curve, even if he says he will consider it.
He was my LAB INSTRUCTOR for the 2211 lab.  I thought he was very knowledgeable and extremely helpful.  Wish I had him for the 2212 lecture... got stuck with Whitenton...

Boatloads of information to study! Good study notes provided by the teacher. Helpful audio, for learning. You will need to study very hard for a B. Testing: hard, short amount of time given. Interesting class. No curve given. Labs not easy.

Calc based Physics 2. The only reason I did well in the class was his tests. Open book, open note multiple choice tests that were fairly easy. I'm not an EE major for a reason, most of the class makes no sense to me. He's fine as a teacher and does a lot of examples. He's probably the easiest Physics prof from what I hear.
If you want an easy A, don't even bother venturing into an Astronomy classroom - not going to happen. I would say that a certain passion for Astronomy is an unsaid prerequisite for taking the class.

Class started off easy but got much harder later on. The examples he would do in class were always much easier than the tests. The test questions would always be a level harder and longer than anything we had done before. He always wanted to make the tests too long and i couldn't stay long because I had a class right after it.
hard to get even a B. Too much studying and you won't get a good result. tricky questions on the test. don't take him if you can.

He is a great teacher. You learn a lot from the class. But I have to say that his test aren't easy. he says that he won't ask for detail but most of the questions are details.he gards the lab in details too so becarefull when you are doing lab.I love his teaching method he explain everything that is in the text so you don't have much problem when y
I can't agree more with the comment previously written. Avoid!

Horrible.  He's an Astronomy professor, not a Physics professor.  Tests questions are not from questions provided to study.  He's shaky and nervous when he talks...very distracting.  And he's a di*k.  Do NOT take this professor for Physics.  If he's the only one available...take a semester off of Physics.
